line-6442: Your affectionate friend, brother, and servant in Christ,
line-6446: My Dear Brethren, Reedy Island, May 21, 1740.
line-6447: For so I call you, because you, and I, and all, have one
line-6448: common father. One God, in whom we live, move and
line-6449: have our beings We all came at first out of the dust of the
line-6450: earth. For after God made the sun, moon, stars, and every
line-6451: thing you see, he also made a creature called man, and breathed
line-6452: into him the breath of life; he then became a living soul.
line-6453: He could not only walk and speak, but he could also think,
line-6454: and reason, and was full of goodness, peace, and joy. This
line-6455: man, this happy creature God placed in a garden, which his
line-6456: own right hand had planted. He then caused him to fall
line-6457: asleep, and out of one of his ribs made what we call a woman,
line-6458: that she might be his wife. Their names were Adam and
line-6459: Eve. With these, God made an agreement that they should
line-6460: eat of every tree of that garden, except one; but if they ate
line-6461: the fruit of that particular tree, they should die; they should
line-6462: return to the dust from whence they were taken, lose the
line-6463: comforts they enjoyed in their souls, and be unhappy for ever
line-6464: in another world. But if they did not eat this fruit, none of
line-6465: these things should come upon them. A being, which we
line-6466: call the devil, (and who for his pride had been cast out of hea-
line-6467: ven) envying their happiness, tempted them to eat the forbidden
line-6468: fruit. They consented, they ate, they died. Their bodies
line-6469: became mortal, their souls were deprived of the presence and
line-6470: love of God; and unless a way was found out to make
line-6471: satisfaction for what they had done, they must have been lost
line-6472: for ever. These were our parents, and God made this agree-
line-6473: ment with us their children, as well as with them. For they
line-6474: acted in our name, as a king acts in the name of his people,
line-6475: or a father in the name of a child—What therefore befell
line-6476: them, befell us. "We died in them; and come into this world
line-6477: poor and miserable, blind and naked, as they were, when they
line-6478: had eaten of the forbidden tree. Hence it is, that we are
line-6479: given to lust, anger, envy, hatred, pride, and malice, and
line-6480: all those troublesome passions which you all must feel in your
line-6481: own hearts, and cannot but see even in the hearts of your chil-
line-6482: dren. If then, you only look into yourselves, you must con-
line-6483: fess these things are so. But God hath given us a book, where-
line-6484: in he assures us of the truth of all this: — And we know that
line-6485: book came from God, because none but God could tell us
line-6486: the things therein contained. And I speak first of this, be-
line-6487: cause till you feel and believe this, you cannot come to the
line-6488: knowledge of Jesus Christ; and without the knowledge
line-6489: of Jesus Christ you cannot be saved. For after our first
line-6490: parents, Adam and Eve, had taken the forbidden fruit, and
line-6491: with all their children, thereafter to be born, became guilty
line-6492: before God, God out of his own free love sent his only be-
line-6493: gotten Son into the world, to die, and so to make an atone-
line-6494: ment for the sin of fallen man, and also to obey the law,
line-6495: which man had broken; so that though fallen man had no
line-6496: righteousness of his own, yet upon believing in God's Son,
line-6497: he should find a perfect righteousness in him. This Son is
line-6498: called Jesus, "A Saviour," because he was to save us from
line-6499: the guilt and power of our sins. He was truly God,
line-6500: and therefore could satisfy; he was truly man, and there-
line-6501: fore could obey and suffer in our stead. He was God and
line-6502: man in one person, that God and man might be happy to-
line-6503: gether again. My dear brethren, (for so I must call you,
line-6504: though I never saw you) these are strange things, but if
line-6505: you are willing to learn, the Holy Spirit shall teach you. For
line-6506: Jesus Christ by dying, and obeying God's law, hath
line-6507: bought for us the Holy Spirit, who shall change your corrupt
line-6508: natures, and fit you for happiness hereafter with the ever-blessed
line-6509: God, if you do but believe in your hearts.—Thousands of
line-6510: white people only believe in their heads, and therefore are no
line-6511: more Christians than those who never heard of Jesus Christ
line-6512: at all. They call Christ, "Lord, Lord," but they do
line-6513: not live as Jesus Christ hath commanded. No, they curse
line-6514: and swear, they break the Sabbath, they get drunk, they play,
line-6515: they whore, they commit adultery, and have taught many poor
line-6516: Indians to do these abominable things as well as themselves.
line-6517: Do not you therefore learn of them. For true Christians are
line-6518: sober, chaste and holy. They will not get drunk, they will
line-6519: not play the whore, they will not cheat, lie, curse or swear;
line-6520: but they will bless and praise God, keep the Sabbath, and do
line-6521: all the good they can; for thus Jesus Christ, their Lord
line-6522: and master, lived when he was here on earth. I say, when
line-6523: he was here on earth; for after he died, he rose again, and
line-6524: went up into heaven from whence he came, and there he sits
line-6525: praying for all that shall believe on Him to the end of the
line-6526: world. For as the world had a beginning, so it also will have
line-6527: an end. And Jesus Christ will come again in the clouds to
line-6528: judge all mankind; and then he that hath believed in Christ,
line-6529: and hath shown forth his faith by his works, shall be saved;
line-6530: and he that hath not believed in Christ, shall be damned for
line-6531: ever, and be cast into a lake of fire and brimstone. But be-
line-6532: fore he comes, he hath promised that the heathen shall be
line-6533: brought to believe on him, and therefore I write this letter to
line-6534: you. I would come myself, and preach the glad tidings of
line-6535: salvation among you, as the bearer of this could interpret for
line-6536: me; but my other business will not permit. I am a minis-
line-6537: ter of the same Jesus, and once was as ignorant of Him com-
line-6538: paratively as you may be. I once lived like other people;
line-6539: but the Lord Jesus hath brought me to believe on Him,
line-6540: and I now do so no more. I once was full of envy, hatred,
line-6541: malice, and such like cursed tempers; but now I have love,
line-6542: and peace, and joy. And because Jesus Christ hath shown
line-6543: such mercy to me, I desire that all others should be made as
line-6544: happy, nay happier than I am myself. — Hearken therefore
line-6545: now to the voice of the Lord. Pray to God that you may
line-6546: feel yourselves poor, miserable sinners, and come by a living
line-6547: faith to Jesus Christ. Then he will pardon you of all

line-6553: lusts. Whosoever will follow Jesus Christ, though happy

line-6567: He who brings this, no doubt, will be despised amongst them,

line-6685: To the Members of a Society at Philadelphia.
line-6686: My dear Friend, Ready Island, May 22, 1740.

line-6688: but send you a line as a token of my unfeigned concern
line-6689: for the welfare of your better part. I must confess, that the
line-6690: account many of you gave of your experiences, was not so
line-6691: satisfactory as I could wish; but I hope you will none of you
line-6692: rest in good desires, or think you are Christians, because you
line-6693: have followed after me. I thank you, God knows my heart,

line-9133: weather as well as wind. O that you would call the family

line-9983: I have enjoyed the especial presence of God ever since I
line-9984: came to London. I preach three times daily. The Lord
line-9985: is remarkably with me. Congregations increase. I am going
line-9986: to have a society-room joined to the tabernacle. The Lord is
line-9987: really on our side. —O let us be meek and quiet! O let us
line-9988: wait, and we shall see the salvation of God. I preach daily
line-9989: at Deptford. Our dear Master helps me to preach and pray
line-9990: with great power. Your ministry hath been blessed. Let us

line-9997: Reverend and dear Sir, London, June 4, 1741.
line-9998: I have now a little time to myself. I must improve it and
line-9999: answer your kind letter. Blessed be God, for enabling
line-10000: me to write anything that may be of service to his church,
line-10001: and of comfort to your soul. Glory be to our dear and com-
line-10002: mon Lord, his cause here succeeds. Truth gets ground.
line-10003: The Lord strengthens me mightily. His power is manifested
line-10004: in our congregations. Conversion work is going on apace
line-10005: among us. I am not yet determined about the exact time of
line-10006: coming to Scotland: but I believe, I shall be with you in
line-10007: about three months. I can't but think the associate presbytery
line-10008: are a little too hard upon me. If I am neuter as to the par-
line-10009: ticular reformation of church government till I have further
line-10010: light, it will be enough. I come simply to preach the gospel,
